perturbation.original_text: 13.1 Marketing Activities and Funds. For each Month during the term of this Agreement, you agree to contribute an amount up to two percent (2%) of Gross Revenues to be allocated in the manner described in Section 13.2 below (the "Marketing Contribution"). The Marketing Contribution is payable and/or allocated in the manner and at the times required under Section 4.3 above (and as otherwise provided in this Section 13).
perturbation.changed_text: 13.1 Marketing Activities and Funds. For each Month during the term of this Agreement, you agree to contribute to marketing activities (the "Marketing Contribution"). The Marketing Contribution is payable and/or allocated in the manner and at the times required under Section 4.3 above (and as otherwise provided in this Section 13).
perturbation.explanation: By omitting the clear 2% limit on the Marketing Contribution of Gross Revenues. This change introduces ambiguity and internal contradiction, given Section 4.3 specifies payment times, but without a clear percentage or amount, the enforcement is now uncertain.

perturbation.original_text: 4.2.9 the term "Royalty Fee" is charged in consideration of you and your Managers' and Producers' use of our business processes, ongoing carrier relationships, trade secrets, know-how, trade names, trademarks, service marks, logos, emblems, trade dress, intellectual property, and back office support functions. The Royalty Fee will be the following amounts: (a) the greater of (i) twenty percent (20%) of Gross Revenues on insurance policies in their initial term, or (ii) the Minimum Royalty (defined below); and (b) fifty percent (50%) of Gross Revenues on policies in their renewal terms and policies written for existing customers on the same risk profile within a one-year period of the cancellation of their existing policy (also known as "re-writes").
perturbation.changed_text: 4.2.9 the term "Royalty Fee" is charged in consideration of you and your Managers' and Producers' use of our business processes, ongoing carrier relationships, trade secrets, know-how, trade names, trademarks, service marks, logos, emblems, trade dress, intellectual property, and back office support functions. The Royalty Fee will be the following amounts: (a) the greater of (i)  Gross Revenues on insurance policies in their initial term, or (ii) the Minimum Royalty (defined below); and (b) fifty percent (50%) of Gross Revenues on policies in their renewal terms and policies written for existing customers on the same risk profile within a one-year period of the cancellation of their existing policy (also known as "re-writes").
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'twenty percent (20%)' from the initial royalty calculation, the modified text contradicts the basic calculation method. The initial royalty becomes ill-defined (greater of (i) Gross Revenues or (ii) Minimum Royalty) while renewal policies still have a defined fee percentage of 50%. This contradiction creates a situation where initial royalty calculations are unclear but renewal royalties are not, leading to enforcement uncertainty and potential legal disputes regarding the payable royalty amount.

perturbation.original_text: 4.7 Index. We have the right to adjust, for inflation, all fixed-dollar amounts under this Agreement (except for the Initial Franchise Fee) once a year to reflect changes in the Index from the year in which you signed this Agreement. For the purpose of this Section 4.8, the term "Index" means the Consumer Price Index (1982- 84=100; all items; CPI-U; all urban consumers) as published by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics ("BLS"). If the BLS no longer publishes the Index, then we will have the right to designate a reasonable alternative measure of inflation.
perturbation.changed_text: 4.7 Index. We have the right to adjust, for inflation, all fixed-dollar amounts under this Agreement (except for the Initial Franchise Fee) once a year to reflect changes in the Index from the year in which you signed this Agreement. For the purpose of this Section 4.8, the term "Index" means the Consumer Price Index (1982- 84=100; all items; CPI-U; all urban consumers). If the BLS no longer publishes the Index, then we will have the right to designate a reasonable alternative measure of inflation.
perturbation.explanation: By removing  'as published by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics ("BLS")' when defining the term "Index," this creates an internal contradiction. The remaining text still references 'Index' and allows the designation of a reasonable alternative measure of inflation if the BLS no longer publishes the Index. However, without linking the primary definition to the BLS, it is now unclear who publishes the Consumer Price Index, and thus, leaves room for ambiguity and disputes.
